Sulfur-free transition metal carbide and nitride catalysts have been shown to be reasonable substitutes for sulfidic catalysts for the hydrotreating middle distillates and vegetable oils. However, their catalyst activity is still lower than commercial catalysts. In this paper, we build on our previous research by studying the synthesis and testing of nine sulfur-free Al2O3-supported Co-Mo nitride catalysts for the hydrotreating of atmospheric gasoil and its blends with rapeseed oil (25 wt.%) under industrial conditions (330–350 °C, 5.5 MPa, WHSV 1–2 h−1). Nitration temperatures play the most significant role in the synthesis and activity of the catalyst, obtaining a CoMoNx catalyst whose catalytic behaviour competes with the current commercial sulfidic Ni-Mo or Co-Mo catalysts (reduction of sulfur and nitrogen content up to 99.0 and 84.0%, respectively). Thus, our results allow us to evaluate and define the most suitable synthesis conditions for preparing high activity sulfur-free Al2O3-supported Co-Mo nitride catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Molybdenum nitride Nitride catalysts Hydrotreatment Sulfur Vegetable oil Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Currently, the problem is the lack of fuels, which must meet high demands related to environmental protection. The EU's environmental strategy is clear, aiming to reduce greenhouse gases and reach zero emissions over the next 30 years. Therefore, it is necessary to find an energy source that could be integrated into existing infrastructure and reduce the environmental impacts of the production and use of fuels. One of the most optimal ways to process oils into biofuels is the transesterification or hydrotreatment pathways due to the higher utilisation ratio of the carbon sources. The process of hydrotreatment of triglyceride has two basic steps: decomposition of triglyceride by β-elimination to produce fatty acids and deoxygenating intermediate fatty acids to form diesel-like hydrocarbons. In the hydrotreatment of triglycerides, there are two main groups of catalysts [1]. The first is composed of noble metals (Pd or Pt) [2–4], and the second is sulfided transition metal (mix of Ni, Mo or Co) catalyst [3,5,6,7]. Current research focuses on the co-processing of vegetable oil with a middle distillate using a sulfur-free catalyst, as the sulfur content of fuels is strictly limited [8]. The nitrides and carbides of some metals could be a good solution. The co-processing includes specifically hydrodenitrogenation (HDN), hydrodesulfurisation (HDS), hydrodearomatization (HDA) and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [9]. The activity of molybdenum nitrides and carbides is comparable to or higher than commercial sulfide catalysts [10,11]. The advantages of molybdenum catalysts are their availability and lower cost, which can be a solid reason for following research and subsequent application on an industrial scale [12]. The nitridation of the supported molybdates usually prepares the molybdenum nitrides. The molybdates are prepared using an incipient wetness technique with an aqueous solution of ammonium heptamolybdate (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O. This precursor is added dropwise to support the formation of molybdates with ammonia in a temperature-programmed mode, to obtain supported nitrides catalysts [13]. Few works are focused on molybdenum carbide and nitride catalyst [14,15] or nickel-molybdenum carbide [16, 17, 18] or cobalt-molybdenum carbide [19] used for hydrotreating of vegetable oil to biofuels production. The hydrotreating (HDO, HDS and HDN) potential of Ni-Mo and Co-Mo carbides and nitrides was investigated mainly on model molecules. Different types of vegetable oils are often used to determine the degree of HDO, where the effectiveness of these catalysts in removing oxygen from the COOH group is investigated. In the case of Ni-Mo carbides, their effectiveness has been studied, for example, on soybean oil [16]. In a bench-scale flow reactor at 400 °C and 650 psi, a NiMoC/Al-SBA-15 catalyst provided the highest yield of organic liquid product (96%) and selectivity (97%) to hydrocarbons in the boiling range of the diesel fraction. On the other hand, the effectiveness of CoMo carbides, nitrides and sulfides in removing nitrogen (HDN) has been investigated for pyridine [20]. At 380 °C, 1 bar and 20 mL/min hydrogen flow, the Co4Mo6 carbide catalyst show the highest activity for pyridine HDN. Thus, the carbide phase is more structurally stable than other phases with a bit lower activity. HDS has been tested with dibenzothiophene (DBT) [21] on Ni-Mo carbides, where the HDS efficiency of DBT over the Ni-Mo2C catalyst reached 96.25% under the reaction conditions of 330 °C, 3.0 MPa, and WHSV 8 h –1, and the conversion was 1.57 times higher than that of Mo2C. The HDS test with thiophene [22] was also interesting, which found that Al2O3-supported bimetallic nitride and carbide catalysts (Ni2Mo3N/Al2O3, Co3Mo3N/Al2O3, Co3Mo3C/Al2O3), while significantly more active than unpromoted Mo nitride or carbide catalysts. Increasing the activity of NiMo/Al2O3 [12,18] and CoMo/Al2O3 [19] catalysts for the HDS and HDN of diesel fuel by introducing different amounts of phosphorus has also been studied. For example, the efficiency of these catalysts has been tested on commercial feedstocks obtained from refineries [23]. Catalysts were tested in a trickle bed reactor using light gas oil and heavy gas oil derived from Athabasca bitumen in the temperature range 340-370 and 375-400 °C, respectively, at 8.8 MPa. P-doped bimetallic Ni-Mo oxide supported on γ-Al2O3 has been prepared and converted into corresponding carbide, nitride and sulfide materials. However, few studies focused on the synthesis optimisation of these nitrides or carbides catalysts and tested them for commercial feedstocks. In this work, we build on our previous research [24–28] to study the influence of synthesis conditions on CoMoNx catalyst properties and activity during the hydrotreating of atmospheric gas oil and co-processing with rapeseed oil (75/25 wt.%) under industrial conditions (330–350 °C, 5.5 MPa, LHSV 1-2 h−1). The CoMoNx catalysts were characterised by elemental analysis (including metal composition), XRD and N2 physisorption. The catalyst activity was evaluated regarding hydrotreating effectiveness, mainly based on HDS and HDN efficiencies. Our results enabled us to determine the optimal conditions for catalyst synthesis to obtain the most active catalysts for gas oil hydrotreating as reasonable substitutes for current commercial sulfidic catalysts. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The Co-Mo/Al2O3 nitride catalysts were synthesised using ammonium heptamolybdate (AHM), hexamethylenetetramine (HMT), ammonia solution (25 wt%) and cobalt nitrate chemicals (all of purity p.a.; Lach-Ner). Al2O3 support (SASOL, spheres 2.5 mm) was crushed and sieved on fraction 0,224–0,560 mm before impregnation. Catalyst reduction and passivation were temperature-programmed-reduction performed using a mixture of 20% H2 in N2 (vol/vol) and 1% O2 in Ar (vol/vol) (both from Linde). N2 gas (99.95% purity) was used for catalyst drying and apparatus cleaning. For hydrotreating testing, atmospheric gas oil (AGO) from industrial atmospheric distillation of Russian export blend crude oil and rapeseed oil (RSO) from food-quality commercial oil were used. The feedstocks and its mixture (AGO/RSO = 75/25 wt.%) were characterised by standard procedures: density (ASTM D 4052; at 20 °C), refractive index (ASTM D 1218; at 20 °C), sulfur (ASTM D 1552) and nitrogen (ASTM D 5291) content, acid number (ASTM D 664), elemental C, H analysis (ISO 29,541) and simulated distillation (Simdis – ASTM D 2887). The total conversion of the triglycerides of RSO into paraffin during co-processing was verified by attenuated total reflection-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR). Standard refinery gas (97.5-99.5 vol% H2 plus 0.5–2.5 vol% CH4) was used as the H2 supply during hydrotreating testing. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis and characterisation Nine sulfur-free Co-Mo nitride catalysts (CoMoNx) were prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method over Al2O3 (Sasol) support, followed by a subsequent temperature-programmed-reduction. The synthesis of these catalytic materials is similar to the methods already described in previous articles for CoMoCx [27] or PMoCx [28] catalyst preparation, and the procedure is briefly described below. The catalyst precursor was prepared according to the following procedure. 45.2 g of molybdate–hexamethylenetetramine complex, which was synthesised from AHM and HMT according to Afanasiev [29], and 21.8 g of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate were dissolved in an aqueous 25% NH3 solution at room temperature (the total volume of the solution was 180 ml). Then, the precursor was loaded into Al2O3 support (120 g, 0.224–0.560 mm) and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. The catalyst was synthesized according to the following procedure. 18 g of the loaded precursor was treated by temperature-programmed-reduction to obtain the CoMoNx catalysts. This process is also called nitridation. For the nitridation, each sample of the loaded precursor was placed in a glass cuvette and thermally treated using 300–500 cm3/min nitridation gas (20 vol% H2 in N2). This process occurred in a 140 cm long and 27 mm internal diameter tubular quartz reactor with a 100 cm triple-zoned electric heater equipped with a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) regulator. The reactor heating started at 200 °C and reached 500-700 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 s. The final temperature was held for 3-9 h. Subsequently, the reactor was cooled down by a nitrogen flow for 30 min. Finally, the catalyst samples were passivated for 2 h by a flow of 1% O2 in Ar gas (75 ml.min−1) to reduce pyrophoric character [11]. The conditions for the nitridation of each catalyst sample are summarised in Table 1 . Different synthesis conditions attend to our aim of studying their effect on catalyst performance and activity. After passivation, each fresh catalyst sample was characterised using the following analytical methods: elemental analysis, X-ray diffraction and N2 physisorption. The details of each catalyst characterisation method are described as follows. 2.2.1 Elemental analysis The metal composition of catalyst samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma with optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) using ICP-EOS Agilent 725 spectrometer (Agilent Technologies Inc., Santa Clara, CA, United States) with echelle optics and a CCD detector. Each sample was prepared for analysis by wet decomposition. The carbon and nitrogen content were determined by an elemental analyser Flash 2000 (Thermo Fisher Scientific S.p.A., Milan, Italy). The principle of this method is the catalytic combustion of the sample in an oxygen environment at a high temperature (950 °C). After the copper reduction of the flue gas, the individual components are separated on a simple chromatographic column and detected by a thermal conductivity detector. 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction - XRD The crystallographic structure of all synthesised catalyst samples in powder form was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis using D8 Advance ECO (Bruker AXS GmbH), applying CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) with the step size of 0.02° and the step time of 0,5 s. During the analysis, the method was optimised, and the parameters step size and step time were changed to 0.04° and 1 s. The patterns were collected in the 2θ range of 5-70° and evaluated using the DIFFRAC.EVA software with the Powder Diffraction File database (PDF 4 + 2018, International Centre for Diffraction Data). 2.2.3 N2 physisorption The textural properties, such as the specific surface area and pore volume, were determined by N2 physisorption. The samples were first degassed under a vacuum at 110 °C for 16 h to remove unwanted vapours and gases adsorbed on the sample surface. Then the adsorption (0.2·10−6–1.0 p/p0) and desorption (1.0-0.05 p/p0) isotherms were measured at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (-195.8 °C). The specific surface area was calculated from the linear plot of the adsorption isotherm using the Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) Method in the pressure range of 0.05–0.30 p/p0. The pore size distribution was determined using the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) equilibrium model, recommended for cylindrical pores and silica-alumina catalysts. The DFT model fit was always up 98.5%. Degassing and the measurement was performed using the Autosorb iQ (Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, FL, USA). 2.3 Experimental setup and catalytic tests The hydrotreating experiments were performed at the experimental facility of ORLEN UniCRE a.s. in Litvínov-Záluží, Czech Republic. The experimental unit was the same previously used by the authors in a previous experiment with carbide catalysts [26]. The unit comprises a bench-scale stainless steel reactor (17 mm internal diameter and 1.08 m length). A triple-zone electric heater heats the reactor, and the temperature is controlled by five thermocouples located in a 5 mm outer diameter thermowell. Fig. 1 shows a schematic diagram of the experimental unit. Prepared samples of catalysts must be immediately placed in the reactor because long storage in air leads to further oxidation of the catalysts [15]. The catalyst bed consisted of four parts of 2.0 g of 0.224-0.560 mm of CoMoNx catalyst (8.0 g in total), dilute with carborundum (SiC - 0.1 mm) in vol:vol ratios of 1:1 (bottom), 1:2, 1:3 and 1:4 (top). This loading schema allows for maintaining the temperature profile in the isothermal regime. Hydrotreating reactions are exothermic, especially during vegetable oil co-processing [30]. After catalyst bed loading, the reactor is flushed with N2 (600 NL h−1) at 100 kPa and 25 °C for 2 h. Then, the catalyst reduction starts, changing the gas to H2 (50 NL h−1), pressure 5.5 MPa and reactor temperature increase to 450 °C at 20 °C h−1. After holding the final temperature for 4 h, it is reduced to 330 °C, the feedstock changed to AGO (16 g h−1), and the H2 flow to g L−1 = 1 NL g−1 h−1. All CoMoNx catalyst samples were tested under the same operating conditions for comparison. Table 2 shows the used operating conditions. Each 4 h of the experiment run, the liquid products were sampled and weighed for mass balancing. During co-processing, the water phase was removed from the hydrotreated gas oil. As a routine analysis, density at 20 °C (ASTM D 4052) and refractive index at 20 °C (ASTM D 1218) were determined for all the samples taken. When these two parameters remained constant with time, it was indicative of the steady-state regime. The hydrotreated gas oil samples collected at steady-state were analysed using the same analytical methods as the feedstock. Gaseous samples were collected in Tedlar bags and analysed offline using Agilent's refinery gas analysis (RGA) method. The instrument used for gas analysis was an Agilent 7890A GC with three channels: (i) A HayeSep Q column with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to measure H2 (N2 carrier gas). (ii) A HayeSep Q column with TCD to measure O2, N2, CO, CO2, SH2, and C1 C2 hydrocarbons (He carrier gas). (iii) A 5A molecular sieve column with flame ionisation detector to measure C1 C7 hydrocarbons (He carrier gas). This instrument uses a commercial method for refinery gas quantification. Gas samples were collected only at the end of each stage at steady-state before the reaction parameters changed. 2.4 Hydrotreatment effectiveness The activity of the catalysts was described in terms of hydrotreating effectiveness, i.e., removing the sulfur and nitrogen compounds from the feedstocks. These parameters can be defined by the following equation, which corresponds to the sulfur/nitrogen mass balances: (1) HDX ( % ) = ( X 0 − ( X p · η ) ) X 0 · 100 X = S , H D S / X = N , H D N where “X0” and “XP” represent the corresponding sulfur/nitrogen contents of the content of the feedstock and liquid product, respectively (wt. ppm), and “η” is the quotient of the quantity of hydrotreating gasoil produced divided by that of the feedstock. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterisation All prepared catalysts were analysed by ICP and elemental analysis for composition, XRD for crystallinity and N2 physisorption for surface area determination. The main characteristics of catalysts in terms of chemical composition, textural properties and crystallinity are shown in Table 3 . The concentration of the active metals (Co and Mo) corresponds to the assumed values of the contents for the individual catalysts. The carbon and nitrogen content obtained by elemental analysis showed a constant carbon content. This point was evident due to using the AHM-HMT complex as a catalyst precursor. During the catalyst preparation, a part of the not sublimate HTM remained in the structure, especially for catalysts prepared at lower temperatures (550–600 °C). The nitrogen content of the dilute decreases from the highest synthesis temperature (700 °C) to the lowest (500 °C) and is related to the formation of nitride phases [15]. From the X-ray diffraction (XRD) results, it is clear that the structure of the prepared catalysts was strongly influenced by the change in the synthesis conditions (Fig. 2 ). Depending on the content of crystalline phases, it is possible to evaluate the samples as very slightly crystalline, microcrystalline (in the case of nitride phases) and amorphous. All synthesised samples contained the characteristics peaks belonging to the used supported: γ-alumina (2theta 37.5°; 45.8° and 66.9°; PDF 80-1385), which accompanies the peaks of the nitride phases of Mo and Co-Mo. These peaks were partially overlapped in the Al2O3 peaks; therefore, it was impossible to reliably identify and further analyse the individual phases in terms of crystallite size. Based on the 39-45° 2theta range analysis, some nitride peaks were detected. Due to the nature of the sample, it was not possible to determine which crystalline phase belongs to the peak at 55 °2theta. The XRD database suggests that the 55° 2theta angle could correspond to aluminium carbide (Al4C3) or molybdenum (MoC), but only trace amounts of carbon were detected by elemental analysis (Table 3). Oxides such as molybdenum oxide (Mo9O26) seem more likely or could be spinel structures of CoAl2O4 or Co3O4, but the formation of spinels is promoted by temperature. This diffraction line appears mainly in samples prepared at lower temperature (Fig. 2c), in samples prepared at 700 °C for 3 h this diffraction line disappears, at this temperature it is visible only at longer synthesis time (9 h) (Fig. 2d). Thus, it is probably a phase transition or a combination of the above described. The most striking result from the XRD analysis was that it seems to follow individual trends. In this sense, more crystalline phases formed with increased metal content (Co + Mo), reaction temperature, synthesis time, and even synthesis gas flow (H2 + N2). At lower temperatures (500-550 °C), the nitride crystalline phases practically do not occur, and at the same time, no oxide structures were observed (MoO3, MoO2, Co3O4, and similar), which indicated an excellent dispersion of Co and Mo on the support surface. The absence of nitride crystalline phases at lower temperatures was also supported by elemental analysis results (Table 3). From the data obtained by XRD and elemental analysis, it can be deduced that at the lowest temperatures (500-550 °C), there is no complete nitrided and most likely either the formation of mixed oxide-nitride phases or only thin nitride layers on the oxide (MoOx-CoOx) surface [24]. The textural properties of the catalysts were determined by N2-physisorption (Fig. 3 ). From these results, it is clear that the catalyst impregnation produced a decrease in the specific surface area and pore volume (Table 3). The higher specific surface area and pore volume report catalysts with a lower content of active metals because the pores were not blocked by the formed nitride or oxide-nitride layers. Neither the temperature nor gas flow had a practical effect on the change in textural properties. However, in the case of changing synthesis time, a decrease of 15% was observed in the pore volume and the specific surface area. This phenomenon was due to long-time heating and leads to the migration of smaller parts of the active phase and the formation of more prominent parts (Ostwald ageing), which worsens diffusion effects and blocks pores. Based on our previous results with MoNx catalysts with different supports (Al2O3, TiO2 and ZrO2), the catalytic behaviour is dependant on the specific surface [26]. Thus, combined with the XRD results, it is expected that catalytic samples synthesized at the nitridation temperature of 500 – 600 °C exhibits the best catalytic performance. Catalyst synthesis parameters (e.g., temperature, pressure, atmosphere, type of metal, the surface of support, texture, and distribution of pores) affect the growth of crystallites of deposited nanoparticles. Speed of nitration is also influenced by factors such as Tamman temperature and strength of interaction of particles with the Al2O3-support [31]. Tamman temperature for MoO3 is 261° and for CoO 779° [32,33]; for nitride phases, Ttamm cannot be tracked. However, due to their nature, Ttamm will probably be higher than for the oxides (probably like Al2O3 – 886 °C). From this point of view, the possible explanation might be the migration of unreacted MoO3 and subsequent blockage of the pores. The results further show that at higher synthesis temperatures (700 °C), larger pores are formed, around 11 nm, at the expense of pores with a 9 nm diameter typical for this kind of support. This point may be due to the partial formation of a monoclinic version (ɵ - Al2O3), displaced to lower temperatures than normal due to other components in the catalyst [34]. This transition was not visible on XRD due to the decrease in intensity of diffraction lines, which corresponds to the support γ-Al2O3. 3.2 Catalyst activity This section evaluates the hydrotreating activity of CoMoNx catalysts during the hydrotreatment of AGO and co-processing with RSO. From the results of catalyst characterisation, it is clear that the synthesis conditions play a significant role in catalyst properties and activity. Table 4 shows the basic properties of the feedstocks used during the experiment, and the results of the table are consistent with the nature of the feedstocks. The hydrotreating activity of CoMoNx catalysts was evaluated in terms of HDS and HDN efficiencies (Eq. (1)). These parameters were determined at each set of operating conditions once the steady-state was achieved, indicated by constant values of density and refractive index at 20 °C with time. Fig. 4 shows the HDS and HDN efficiencies of CoMoNx catalysts at different operating temperatures (330, 340 and 350 °C) synthesised under different conditions. In the first term, these catalysts behave similarly to industrial hydrotreating catalysts. It means that higher operating temperatures or lower WHSV increases catalyst activity. This behaviour has already been described in previous articles in detail [15]. Related to the synthesis conditions, most of their variations changed the hydrotreating activity slightly. However, the situation was different in the case of nitration temperature, which seems to play the most crucial role in catalyst activity. This parameter directly affects the surface area and particle size of catalysts, identified as the mains responsible for the hydrotreating catalyst activity [35]. As references [11] described, nitriding temperatures ∼ 500 °C mean forming γ-Mo2N species, which are transformed to γ-Mo2N0.78 and Mo metal at higher temperatures. The hydrogen adsorption of Mo2N species is comparable with Mo2C and MoS2 species. Thus, a significant catalyst activity of MoNx catalysts is expected during hydrotreating. The catalyst activity would be even higher for bimetallic catalysts due to the effect of the promotor by adding Ni, P or Co, as in the current study [36]. Regarding HDS and HDN efficiencies, the catalysts synthesised at 500-550 °C produced a hydrotreating gas oil with sulfur and nitrogen compounds content of < 100 and < 50 ppm, respectively. The high activity of CoMoNx 3-14/500–550/300/3 can be clearly attributed to the very well dispersed CoMo nitride or nitride-oxide phase deposited on the surface of the Al2O3 support, which does not form crystalline structures and is rather nanocrystalline to amorphous. This fact shows the feasibility of obtaining a CoMoNx/Al2O3 catalyst with a hydrotreating activity [11] comparable to the conventional sulfidic catalyst, commonly used at an industrial scale for fuel desulfurisation [37]. CoMoNx catalysts were also tested for the co-processing of AGO with RSO as reasonable substitutes for commercial sulfidic catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the HDS and HDN efficiencies of CoMoNx catalysts synthesised at different operating conditions during the co-processing of a mixture of 75% AGO and 25% RSO. As can be seen in these results, adding RSO to the feedstock for hydrotreating meant a decrease in HDS and HDN efficiencies. In most of the catalysts, this decrease was not so significant and higher in the case of HDN efficiency. The catalyst deactivation during co-processing has already been described in references. It is attributable to several factors, such as (i) coking on catalyst surface due to exothermic character of triglycerides hydrotreating [30,38] and (ii) catalyst active sites inhibition by the adsorption of side products (H2O, CO/CO2) [39]. The highest deactivation was detected in those catalysts with lower content of active metals (Fig. 5a and b), where a decrease of the active sites is directly related to lower catalyst activity. Despite catalyst deactivation detected during co-processing, this fact did not affect the complete conversion of triglycerides into n-alkanes, which was verified by ATR-IR [40]. In the same way, SIMDIS analysis showed an n-alkanes distribution with a predominance of hydrodeoxygenation pathway (HDO) instead of the (hydro) decarboxylation/decarbonylation pathways (DCO). This behaviour is similar to previous MoCx, Ni/Co-Mo-Cx and P-MoCx catalysts, which have been already described in previous authors' works [26–28], where the HDS and HDN efficiencies was significantly lower than the CoMoNx catalysts described in this study. For example, CoMoCx/Al2O3 catalysts had hydrodesulfurisation efficiency of 80% at 350 °C [27] or for the phosphorus promoted molybdenum carbide (PMoCx) catalysts were hydrodesulfurization and hydrodenitrogenation for both only to 55% [28]. 4 Conclusions This work studies the influence of synthesis conditions of sulfur-free CoMoNx/Al2O3 catalyst on properties and activity for hydrotreating atmospheric gas oil and its blends with rapeseed oil (25 wt.%) at common industrial conditions (330–350 °C, 5.5 MPa and WHSV 1–2 h−1). From these results, it is possible to claim that the synthesis conditions, specially nitridation temperature, play a significant role in the catalyst properties and activity. In this sense, on the side of catalyst characterisation, nitridation temperatures in the range of 500-550 °C provided an excellent dispersion of active metals and promotors (i.e., Co and Mo) in the catalyst support, together with a satisfactory formation of γ-Mo2N species, confirmed by the presence of nitrogen and the absence of oxide structures in the catalyst. In the same way, the catalyst synthesised at these conditions (denoted as CoMo 3-14/500-550/300/3), exhibited HDS and HDN efficiencies comparable to commercial sulfured catalysts (99.0 and 84.0, respectively), together with no relevant effect of rapeseed oil addition (< 5% in both cases). Our results evaluated and defined the most optimal conditions to produce sulfur-free CoMoNx/Al2O3 with a competitive catalyst activity regarding the conventional sulfured catalysts, assuming a reasonable ratio of vegetable oil co-processing in line with challenging Green Deal directives for upcoming years. coredata.dc:description: Sulfur-free transition metal carbide and nitride catalysts have been shown to be reasonable substitutes for sulfidic catalysts for the hydrotreating middle distillates and vegetable oils. However, their catalyst activity is still lower than commercial catalysts. In this paper, we build on our previous research by studying the synthesis and testing of nine sulfur-free Al2O3-supported Co-Mo nitride catalysts for the hydrotreating of atmospheric gasoil and its blends with rapeseed oil (25 wt.%) under industrial conditions (330–350 °C, 5.5 MPa, WHSV 1–2 h−1). Nitration temperatures play the most significant role in the synthesis and activity of the catalyst, obtaining a CoMoNx catalyst whose catalytic behaviour competes with the current commercial sulfidic Ni-Mo or Co-Mo catalysts (reduction of sulfur and nitrogen content up to 99.0 and 84.0%, respectively). Thus, our results allow us to evaluate and define the most suitable synthesis conditions for preparing high activity sulfur-free Al2O3-supported Co-Mo nitride catalysts.
